Patch Set 1:

Design document for adding System Power Mode and Idle Power Saver support

Patch Set 9:

What is the status on this?

Patch Set 10:

> Patch Set 9:
>

Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

Seems good to me. 
Please just update when the Redfish schemas come out.
Change has been successfully merged by Patrick Williams
should we explain OCC or expand it at least once ?
Is this public? Can you just add it here?
P10 is not public yet.  I could add link to the public P9 spec, but it does not contain changes required for p10.

I think this falls under: https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/0f6c884822ca2d101e2a0bf3256ecf4f6f2431a3/CONTRIBUTING.md#references-to-non-public-resources

"References to non-public resources

Code and commit messages shall not refer to companies' internal documents or systems (including bug trackers). Other developers may not have access to these, making future maintenance difficult.

Code contributed to OpenBMC must build from the publicly available sources, with no dependencies on non-public resources (URLs, repositories, etc)."

Can we remove? Can we make public?
Can't make public until closer to GA, so I will just remove.

This will be a Redfish API? 
We plan to ask Redfish to add something here?
Could you add more about the Redfish API?
Will this be available on the GUI?

Yes it will be available on the GUI.  More details are described in the Requirements section above (should I move/copy them here?)
I am not sure on what the options are here.  If new interfaces all use Redfish, then I would expect this to use as well.  Need some guidance on what is needed for this.
No need to copy them here but can you add more about the Redfish interface / GUI interface in the requirements section? At least mention Redfish.

I think you'll need to mention which pieces of this are POWER processor specific, or rather that this only applies to POWER processors, since OpenBMC supports something like 4 different processor architectures.  I assume basically it all is.
Pleaes move to an IBM or Power subdirectory.
I think this would all go in openpower-occ-control?  You could mention that here.
Just curious, does the driver currently expose this in sysfs?  Or are there changes needed there?

The response header (containing the state) is part of the occ structure, but I assume that entire object is only known to the driver.  Looks like all the exposed temperatures, frequencies, and power values all have sensors created by the driver.
So I am assuming that there needs to be some sensor created that would need to get written by the driver.  Unless the driver can detect the state change and trigger some event that calls the occ-control code.
Are these OEM Redfish profiles or common ones?
Think these will have to be OEM.

Ed added a new document about OEM in bmcweb: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39016 

Can you read and make sure you still think these should be OEM ?

This is a bit of nit-pick, but what's written isn't a problem statement, but a statement of intent.

A problem statement would read something like:

> Power management on POWER platforms needs assistance from the BMC for managing power and idle modes. We need capabilities X, Y and Z in OpenBMC in order to provide the necessary BMC support.

The idea is to make clear what OpenBMC currently *lacks* that you require.
Again, these are statements about what you plan to add, rather than information about the problem.
_This_ is the right kind of stuff! Thanks.

What code sends it where?

Can you talk about why the BMC has to be involved? You may need to talk more about how these systems are managed in a broad sense.
Can you provide more of a description of what the "actual OCC state" is?
How are these different to other vendors designs? They sound pretty generic. Can we leverage common interfaces?
Extra two bytes compared to what?
These sound like they may be POWER-specific, but it would be nice to confirm by asking around.

I think this needs to be explored a bit more. How does it impact applications in OpenBMC? Are there new D-Bus interfaces that need to be agreed on? What applications implement them? How do they communicate with the OCC?
Nothing concrete has really been described there though. I'm struggling to imagine what the Redfish equivalent would look like. I think we need more detail in the requirements section and also here.
But what do these APIs look like?

Is this automated or manual testing? If it's manual, who is responsible for making sure it works on an on-going basis?

I also feel like there's going to be code written to support this. It seems strange to think that it couldn't be unit-tested?
Can you point to the real schema changes now then?  Have a link to a private github issue isn't too helpful for anyone who isn't a member of DMTF.
The real schema changes aren't out yet..

Power modes were part of 2021.1. From https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43376/1/static/redfish/v1/schema/ComputerSystem_v1.xml#2310

      <EnumType Name="PowerMode">
        <Member Name="MaximumPerformance">
          <Annotation Term="OData.Description" String="The system performs at the highest speeds possible."/>
          <Annotation Term="OData.LongDescription" String="This value shall indicate the system performs at the highest speeds possible.  This mode should be used when performance is the top priority."/>
        </Member>
        <Member Name="BalancedPerformance">
          <Annotation Term="OData.Description" String="The system performs at the highest speeds while utilization is high and performs at reduced speeds when the utilization is low."/>
          <Annotation Term="OData.LongDescription" String="This value shall indicate the system performs at the highest speeds possible when the utilization is high and performs at reduced speeds when the utilization is low to save power.  This mode is a compromise between `MaximumPerformance` and `PowerSaving`."/>
        </Member>
        <Member Name="PowerSaving">
          <Annotation Term="OData.Description" String="The system performs at reduced speeds to save power."/>
          <Annotation Term="OData.LongDescription" String="This value shall indicate the system performs at reduced speeds to save power.  This mode should be used when power saving is the top priority."/>
        </Member>
        <Member Name="Static">
          <Annotation Term="OData.Description" String="The system power mode is static."/>
          <Annotation Term="OData.LongDescription" String="This value shall indicate the system performs at a static base speed."/>
        </Member>
        <Member Name="OSControlled">
          <Annotation Term="OData.Description" String="The system power mode is controlled by the operating system."/>
          <Annotation Term="OData.LongDescription" String="This value shall indicate the system performs at a operating system controlled power mode."/>
        </Member>
        <Member Name="OEM">
          <Annotation Term="OData.Description" String="The system power mode is OEM-defined."/>
          <Annotation Term="OData.LongDescription" String="This value shall indicate the system performs at an OEM-defined power mode."/>
        </Member>
      </EnumType>

Can we define the dbus-interfaces?  (I prefer if they're in phosphor-dbus-interfaces rather than dual-documented in this doc as well.)  Are we still awaiting resolution on the Redfish design (issue/4386)?
